CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection allowed (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Violation of Art. 8;No separate issue under Art. 6-1;Remainder inadmissible;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses partial award - domestic proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE .

CARDINAL . The applicant was married to PERSON , a NORP national . They lived in GPE . They have a son , PERSON , who was born in DATE . PERSON also had another child , PERSON , who was adopted by the applicant in DATE .
CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the applicant left GPE and in DATE the applicant and PERSON divorced .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON wrote a letter to the Head of ORG requesting that the applicant be banned from entering GPE . PERSON complained , in particular , that in DATE the applicant had come to GPE , GPE , where their son PERSON had been on holidays with a nurse , and had threatened to take ORG away . She further stated that in his previous marriage the applicant had inflicted grievous bodily harm on his wife .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG sent a request to ORG to ban the applicant from entering GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the ORG that Mr. PERSON was prohibited from entering GPE for DATE . The applicant learned about this decision shortly afterwards .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant was informed by PERSON , his lawyer in another civil case , that his former wife had lodged a claim with the Pechersky District Court of GPE seeking to deprive the applicant of his parental rights with respect to his natural son PERSON applicant could not be present in the court due to the prohibition on entering GPE , but was represented before the court by his lawyer , Mr T.

CARDINAL . On DATE the first - instance court found for PERSON and decided to deprive the applicant of his parental rights . The court based its decision on the fact that the applicant did not fulfil his parental duties properly , in particular he did not participate in bringing up the child , did not contact him and had lost any interest towards him . The court also took into consideration that the applicant had not complained to the local tutelage and supervision board that PERSON refused him access to the child . The court disregarded the applicant 's argument about the impossibility of participating in the up - bringing of the child due to the prohibition on entering the country , stating that the applicant had not met his son since DATE .

According to the Government , the domestic courts had been aware that the applicant had deliberately indicated false data on his place and date of birth in official documents and that he had been previously criminally prosecuted and had never been formally acquitted .

CARDINAL . NORP This decision was appealed against by the applicant 's representative to ORG . In the appeal it was mentioned that the conclusion of the court of first instance that the applicant did not want to meet his son was incorrect , since in her request of DATE to the police PERSON had clearly mentioned his attempt to see their son in DATE . It was also mentioned that the applicant had tried to lodge a request with the tutelage and supervision board of ORG , but had been informed that his presence was required in order for the request to be examined . The representative complained that the court of first instance heard only witnesses of the opposing party , who had been employed by PERSON He noted that the court had not sought to receive first - hand information from the applicant himself through the international legal assistance instruments .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the court of appeal upheld the decision of the first instance court . Having repeated the findings of the first instance court , the court of appeal noted that the applicant 's objections had not been supported by any evidence and the arguments of the opposite side had been confirmed by testimonies of CARDINAL nurses of the child . It further decided that the arguments of the applicant 's appeal did not dispose of the findings of the first - instance court and did not influence the correctness of those findings .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed in cassation . In his appeal he reiterated his previous arguments and complained that the court of appeal refused to call a witness on his behalf .

CARDINAL . On DATE the panel of CARDINAL judges of ORG rejected the applicant 's request for leave to appeal in cassation , having found that the lower courts did not violate any substantive or procedural law .

CARDINAL . NORP By letter of DATE , ORG of GPE informed the applicant 's lawyer that the service abroad of judicial documents could be conducted under the relevant international instruments . In relations between them , GPE and GPE used LAW , DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of GPE examined the applicant 's request to correct the date of his birth in the civil state register . The court decided for the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the same court quashed its previous decision of CARDINAL DATE in the light of newly discovered circumstances and re - opened the proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court rejected the applicant 's request concerning mistake in his date of birth in the register . On DATE and DATE respectively ORG and ORG upheld the decision of the first instance court .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of GPE considered a claim by the applicant , in which he requested to invalidate the decision on adoption of PERSON , the elder son of PERSON , and rejected it as unsubstantiated , having found that at the time of adoption the applicant and PERSON had genuine and good family relations .
CARDINAL . On DATE , the same court invalidated the above - mentioned decision on adoption of PERSON by the applicant .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG rejected the applicant 's complaint against the decision about prohibition of his entry in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG upheld the decision of the first instance court .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed in cassation . The proceedings are still pending .
CARDINAL . The relevant extracts of the LAW of GPE read as follows :
Article CARDINAL

“ Foreigners and stateless persons who are in GPE on legal grounds enjoy the same rights and freedoms and also bear the same duties as citizens of GPE , with the exceptions established by the LAW , laws or international treaties of GPE ... ”
Article CARDINAL
“ No one shall be subject to interference in his or her personal and family life , except in cases envisaged by LAW ... ”
Article CARDINAL
“ ... The family , childhood , motherhood and fatherhood are under the protection of the ORG . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code provided that civil proceedings should be conducted on the grounds of equality of persons regardless , in particular , of their place of residence .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code provided that the claimant and the defendant had equal procedural rights .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provided that foreign citizens had equal procedural rights with NORP citizens in civil proceedings . The NORP legislation could foresee restrictions on procedural rights of citizens of other countries , where the procedural rights of NORP citizens were restricted .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code provided that parents could be deprived of their parental rights if it was established that they neglected their duties of bringing up their children , or abused their parental rights , treated the children cruelly , influenced the children harmfully by their immoral , antisocial behaviour , as well as when the parents were chronic alcoholics or drug addicts . The deprivation of parental rights did not preclude the possibility for a person concerned to seek access to the child through the courts .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL established the circle of persons entitled to seek deprivation of parental rights before the courts . It also envisaged participation of guardianship authorities and the prosecutor in the hearing .
CARDINAL . This Code replaced LAW and contains similar provisions as to deprivation of parental rights .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that foreigners can marry and divorce NORP citizens under NORP law . They have equal rights in family relations with NORP citizens .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL provides that foreigners are entitled to seek protection of their individual , property and other rights in the courts and other state bodies . In judicial proceedings foreigners have equal procedural rights with NORP citizens .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL stipulates that entry to GPE can be prohibited to a foreigner in the interests of national security and public order , if public health , the protection of the rights and legitimate interests of NORP citizens and residents require so , if the foreigner violated NORP legislation during his previous stay in GPE , etc .
